content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple sections of tissue on a single slide, likely from a lymph node dissection. I can identify approximately nine discrete, ovoid to circular structures that are characteristic of lymph nodes. Some of these nodes appear uniformly basophilic (dark purple), suggesting they might be reactive or uninvolved. Others show paler, irregular areas, which are suspicious for metastatic deposits. At the bottom left, there is a larger, more irregularly shaped tissue fragment with a mottled appearance, suggesting it could be a heavily infiltrated lymph node that has lost its typical architecture, or possibly a section of the primary tumor.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I would zoom into this area because the tissue fragment at the bottom left is highly suspicious. Unlike the other more defined lymph nodes, this one is large, has an irregular border, and lacks the typical architecture of a lymph node (e.g., a distinct cortex and medulla). The mixed pink and purple staining pattern suggests a combination of inflammatory/lymphoid cells and another process, such as tumor infiltration with a desmoplastic stromal response. The primary goal is to determine if this represents a lymph node completely replaced by tumor, and to assess for potential extranodal extension (tumor spreading beyond the lymph node capsule). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. The green box highlights an area within the pericolic/perinodal adipose tissue, adjacent to a large tissue fragment in the lower left that appears to be an infiltrated lymph node. I would zoom into this specific area to meticulously examine the soft tissue for prognostically critical findings beyond the lymph node itself. My primary goals would be to search for: 
1. Extranodal extension (ENE) from the adjacent lymph node.
2. Isolated tumor deposits (TDs) separate from the lymph node.
3. Lymphovascular invasion (LVI).
4. Perineural invasion (PNI).
These features significantly impact staging and patient prognosis, so any subtle density or structure in the fat must be evaluated at high power. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am examining the fourth lymph node from the top, located on the left side of the slide. A pathologist must systematically review every lymph node from edge to edge. I zoomed into this specific peripheral area to inspect the lymph node capsule, the subcapsular sinus, and the adjacent perinodal fat. This region is critical because metastatic cells often arrive via afferent lymphatics and first colonize the subcapsular sinus. It is also essential to check the perinodal fat for any extranodal extension of the tumor, which has prognostic significance. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this specific area because it is within a lymph node that appears heterogeneous on low power. The green box targets the interface between the residual lymphoid tissue (dark purple area) and the surrounding sinus/stroma. This subcapsular or sinusoidal region is a common location for early metastatic deposits to arrive. Even at this low magnification, the area within the box has a different texture and a more 'infiltrative' appearance compared to the dense, uniform lymphoid tissue, raising suspicion for a cluster of non-lymphoid, potentially malignant, cells that require high-power examination for confirmation. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I need to examine every lymph node to check for metastasis. This area, containing one of the smaller lymph nodes in the upper left (the second from the top on the left side), is a logical starting point for a systematic review. All nodes, regardless of their low-power appearance, must be inspected at higher magnification to confidently rule out micrometastases. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because this particular lymph node (the third from the top, second from the right) shows classic signs of being a positive (metastatic) node. The normal lymphoid architecture is almost completely effaced and replaced by a large, confluent, dark purple cellular mass. There is also a central, paler pink area, which could represent tumor necrosis. The goal is to examine these atypical cells at high magnification to confirm they are malignant carcinoma cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the lymph node located in the upper right corner (the 1st node from the top right). At low power, this node has an irregular border where the dense lymphoid tissue interfaces with the surrounding adipose (fatty) tissue. This irregularity is highly suspicious for tumor cells that have breached the lymph node capsule and are infiltrating the surrounding fat. This is known as extranodal extension (ENE), a critical prognostic factor that must be carefully assessed. The zoom is placed precisely at this suspicious interface to confirm or rule out ENE. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the task is to assess every lymph node for the presence of metastasis. I would systematically examine each one. The selected area, indicated by the green box, is on the lymph node located on the far right of the slide. At low power, this node appears almost completely replaced by a dense, monotonous population of dark blue cells, a feature known as architectural effacement. While this could be a reactive process, the uniform nature raises suspicion. I would zoom in to closely examine the cytology (the appearance of individual cells) to determine if these are reactive lymphocytes, neoplastic lymphocytes (lymphoma), or, most importantly in this context, metastatic carcinoma cells which can sometimes be small and mimic lymphocytes. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine every piece of tissue submitted. I am zooming into this specific area on the large, irregular tissue fragment at the bottom left because its appearance is highly suspicious for extranodal extension (ENE). Unlike a well-circumscribed metastatic deposit within a lymph node, this area shows a disorganized, infiltrative pattern at the interface with the surrounding fatty tissue. It is crucial to examine this junction at high magnification to determine if the tumor has breached the lymph node capsule and is invading the perinodal adipose tissue, as ENE is a significant adverse prognostic factor that must be reported. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to examine every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. I chose to zoom into this specific lymph node because its appearance at low magnification is abnormal. Unlike a reactive lymph node with a preserved architecture, this node shows irregular, patchy, dark areas infiltrating the normal tissue. This pattern strongly suggests it is a positive (metastatic) lymph node, and I need to confirm the presence of malignant cells at high power and assess for features like extranodal extension. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my protocol is to examine every lymph node on the slide. I have selected this specific lymph node (the one at the bottom center) for closer examination because at low power, its normal architecture appears effaced. Instead of clear cortical and medullary regions with germinal centers, there is an irregular, infiltrative pattern of basophilic tissue mixed with lighter, eosinophilic, and somewhat empty-looking areas. This disruption is highly suspicious for metastatic carcinoma, and high-power examination is required for confirmation. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see residual lymphoid tissue, characterized by small, dark, round lymphocytes, which are being heavily infiltrated and replaced. The dominant feature is a desmoplastic stroma, which is a dense, pink, fibrous tissue response. Embedded within this stroma are nests and poorly formed glands of atypical epithelial cells. These tumor cells are larger than the lymphocytes, have irregular nuclei, and eosinophilic cytoplasm. The overall features are diagnostic of metastatic adenocarcinoma infiltrating a lymph node. The disorganized infiltration into the surrounding fibroadipose tissue is highly suggestive of extranodal extension.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image shows mature adipose tissue (fat cells). At the top, there is a prominent, thick-walled blood vessel, likely an artery, surrounded by a cuff of lymphocytes (a type of inflammatory cell). There are also some scattered lymphocytes and fibrous tissue throughout the field. Crucially, there are no definite malignant epithelial cells (carcinoma) visible in this specific field of view. There is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion, perineural invasion, or a tumor deposit. My impression is that this particular area shows benign fibroadipose tissue with a reactive blood vessel, and the pathologist has effectively ruled out metastatic disease in this specific spot.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see the periphery of a lymph node. On the left, there is a dense sheet of small, dark, round cells, consistent with lymphocytes. This lymphoid tissue is infiltrating into the surrounding mature adipose tissue (fat cells). On the right, there are several prominent, thick-walled blood vessels within fibroconnective tissue. I do not see any definite malignant epithelial cells, such as atypical glands or large pleomorphic cell clusters. My impression of this specific field is that it shows a benign lymph node edge with perinodal fat and blood vessels. There is no evidence of metastasis in this particular view.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see clusters and irregular cords of atypical epithelial cells infiltrating the lymph node sinusoids and surrounding stroma. These cells are much larger than the background small lymphocytes. They exhibit pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei, and some attempt to form poorly defined glandular structures. The surrounding tissue consists of residual lymphocytes, plasma cells, and adipose tissue. My impression is that this is unequivocally metastatic adenocarcinoma, consistent with an origin from a colorectal primary tumor. This finding confirms that this is a positive (metastatic) lymph node.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a lymph node that is densely populated by a monotonous sheet of small, dark-staining lymphocytes. There is some perinodal adipose tissue at the periphery. The normal lymph node architecture (follicles, sinuses) is effaced. However, I do not see any clusters of atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or significant necrosis to suggest metastatic carcinoma. My impression is that this is a lymph node negative for metastasis, although it shows reactive changes or possibly a low-grade lymphoproliferative process.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see a dense, solid sheet of malignant cells on the right, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. These cells are crowded, have high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratios, irregular nuclear contours, and hyperchromatic (dark) chromatin. They show a back-to-back, poorly cohesive growth pattern. On the left, I can see the fibrous capsule of the lymph node and some surrounding adipose tissue. The tumor is directly adjacent to the capsule. My impression is that this is a lymph node unequivocally positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma, consistent with an origin from a colorectal primary.
This is ROI 7. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I can clearly see the junction between the lymph node and the surrounding tissue. On the right is the dense, dark purple lymphoid tissue of the node. On the left is mature adipose tissue. Critically, there are clusters and single atypical epithelial cells infiltrating the adipose tissue, extending beyond the confines of the lymph node parenchyma. These cells are morphologically consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node with definitive evidence of extranodal extension (ENE).
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a dense and monotonous sheet of small, round cells with scant cytoplasm and dark, round nuclei. The normal architecture of the lymph node, such as follicles and sinuses, is completely absent. Crucially, I do not see the typical features of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma, such as glandular formation, large pleomorphic cells with vesicular nuclei, prominent nucleoli, or significant eosinophilic cytoplasm. The cells appear to be lymphoid in origin. My impression is that this lymph node is effaced by a lymphoid process, which is suspicious for a low-grade B-cell lymphoma (like SLL/CLL). For the purpose of staging the colorectal cancer, this specific area and this lymph node would be classified as negative for metastatic carcinoma. The pathologist is likely ruling out metastasis in this node before moving on to examine other, more suspicious-looking nodes on the slide.
This is ROI 9 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see nests and sheets of malignant cells with features of adenocarcinoma (large, pleomorphic nuclei, irregular nuclear contours, and glandular formation). These tumor cells are clearly infiltrating into the surrounding mature adipose tissue (the large, clear, empty-looking cells). There is an associated desmoplastic stromal reaction (the pink fibrous tissue) and a moderate inflammatory infiltrate. A prominent band of smooth muscle is also seen, possibly representing the wall of a large vessel being invaded. My definitive impression is that this is metastatic adenocarcinoma with clear evidence of extranodal extension into the perinodal fat. This is a critical finding for accurate N staging.
This is ROI 10 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, I see a clear demarcation between perinodal adipose tissue (fat cells) on the left and a dense infiltrate of malignant cells on the right. These malignant cells are arranged in poorly-formed glands and solid nests, exhibiting large, dark, irregularly shaped nuclei (pleomorphism and hyperchromasia). This morphology is consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. Crucially, the tumor appears to be breaching the lymph node capsule and infiltrating the surrounding fat. My impression is a positive lymph node with extranodal extension (ENE), which is a critical finding for tumor staging.
This is ROI 11 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, the normal lymph node parenchyma is almost completely replaced by a malignant infiltrate. I see back-to-back and cribriform glands composed of atypical epithelial cells. These cells exhibit marked pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, and prominent nucleoli. There is evidence of 'dirty necrosis' (luminal debris) within the glands. These features are characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma, consistent with a primary colorectal cancer. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node, confirming the presence of metastatic disease.
